docs.lead_paragraph: At the dusty elbow of a ragged road named Lovers Lane sits a corrugated tin barn, dull gray and green against the dun-colored hills of central California. Inside the barn is a big stainless steel tub where greens like radicchio, frisee and arugula, plucked from the nearby fields, are rinsed before being blended into fancy, premixed salads -- a hot item among health-minded consumers these days.

headline.main: Tracing Bout of Illness to Small Lettuce Farm

docs.abstract: Second of three articles in series Fresh Hazards discusses how Federal and state investigators traced outbreak of food poisoning in May and June 1996 to lettuce that was grown by Fancy Cutt Farms of Hollister, Calif; investigators say that lettuce, which was contaminated by E coli bacteria, sickened at least 61 people in Illinois, Connecticut and New York; company denies responsibility for outbreak and continues to sell its lettuce; fact that investigation led to small California farm thousands of miles from victims illustrates how vulnerable nation's far-flung food distribution system is to new contaminants that are puzzling to scientists and causing thousands of illnesses each year; photos (M)

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and CHRISTOPHER DREW

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey smokers can add another incentive to their list of reasons for resolving to quit this year: money. The tobacco tax doubled on New Year's Day, to 80 cents a pack of cigarettes, raising the price to about $2.50 a pack at most outlets. Cigar and pipe smokers, tobacco chewers and snuff users will also pay more.

headline.main: New Tax Laws for the New Year

docs.abstract: Preview of new tax laws slated to go into effect in New Jersey in 1998 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: George Petrenko comes from a long line of doctors. His grandfather was a surgeon, his grandmother was a psychiatrist and his mother was a dermatologist. Most of his relatives in Ukraine are physicians, as well. ''Being doctors, you could say, is in our blood,'' said Mr. Petrenko, 36, a trained physical therapist who shares a Rego Park, Queens, apartment with two other generations of his family.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Immigrant's Medical Career Is Now Just a Memory

docs.abstract: New York Timers Neediest Cases appeal profiles economic hardships Igor Petrenko and family, Ukrainian immigrants in Rego Park, Queens; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NEW YORK TIMES NEEDIEST CASES FUND

docs.lead_paragraph: WILL 1997 go down as the year when the winners finally outnumbered the losers in the assisted-living industry? It just might. When assisted-living companies began a wave of initial public offerings in 1995, their stocks flew high, fueled by rosy expansion plans and $1.4 billion in new capital. But even then most of them were not expected to turn a profit for at least two years.

headline.main: Assisted-Living Stocks Begin to Fulfill Promise

docs.abstract: 1997 may go down as year when winners finally outnumbered losers in assisted-living industry; revenues for $12 billion industry are growing 15 to 20 percent annually; companies, which furnish residences for frail but healthy elderly, are trying to distinguish themselves in crowded field; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''At least 50 percent of all non-hard-sciences research on American campuses is a lot of foolishness!'' declared the speaker, thumping his lectern. The audience of 200 responded with laughter and applause. This wasn't a revival meeting somewhere in the Bible Belt. It was a smartly dressed gathering of the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce at Le Meridien Hotel in the heart of Boston's financial district.
docs.abstract: Criticism of academia's cherished perks and privileges discussed in light of exorbitant tuitions, and recent scathing attack by James F Carlin, chairman of Massachusetts Board of Higher Education; Carlin pointed to faculty rule, research, publications, tenure and sabbaticals, describing cushy life of professors who enjoy long vacations, much free time and every fringe benefit ever devised; photos; others in field, while criticizing such practices, say faculty should not be scapegoats for promotion system based on publications, not teaching (special section, Education Life) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wrapped in a purple overcoat, Maria Rivera sat quietly last Tuesday in the waiting room of the Betances Health Unit, a neighborhood clinic on Henry Street. Like many Betances patients, Ms. Rivera receives Medicaid, and like many, she was unaware that the state has plans to change the way she gets health care. ''Can I still come to Betances?'' she asked in Spanish. ''I've been coming here 17 years.''
docs.abstract: Betances Health Unit, one of 40 or so neighborhood clinics in New York City, expresses financial concerns over plan by New York State to move 1.6 million Medicaid patients into health maintenance organizations; fears plan will steer patients away from them to hospitals and HMO clinics and decrease fees for Medicaid patients; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For chiropractors in New York, 1998 has been touted as the year of the back, the year when insurance companies and managed-care organizations are finally being forced to confer legitimacy on their oft-maligned profession. With the start of the new year, New York became only the third state to mandate coverage for most chiropractors' services. But the new regulations do not have chiropractors looking for more office space, hiring new associates or ordering new cars.
docs.abstract: Chiropractors in New York are gratified by new law mandating coverage for most of their service by health-maintenance organizations, but doubt if they are in for windfall; expect to get more patients but say managed-care companies, seeking to hold down costs of newly required service, will offer them far less than fees they are now charging, which had been covered in full or in part by insurance or paid out of pocket by patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton made a big political commitment to health care for children last year, and Congress agreed to make a big financial investment in a new health insurance program for children.
docs.snippet: President Clinton made a big political commitment to health care for children last year, and Congress agreed to make a big financial investment in a new health insurance program for children.

docs.lead_paragraph: The year 1997 was a rough one for the holders of health care stocks. Columbia/HCA, which had been one of Wall Street's favorite growth companies, saw its once high-flying stock drop from $45 a share in March to $26 in October after the company became the target of a major Federal investigation. Then there was that other Wall Street darling, Oxford Health Plans. Since going public half a dozen years ago, it had been one of the fastest-growing managed care companies in the country. But in October when Oxford stunned the market by announcing its first-ever quarterly loss, shares of the stock lost 63 percent of their value in a single day.

headline.main: The Tarnished Darlings of Wall Street

docs.abstract: Joseph Nocera Op-Ed article says it is disturbing that fall of stock price of health-care companies like Oxford Health Plans and Columbia/HCA is being reported by and large as a Wall Street story, not as one affecting the people the companies serve; says achieving the big annual profit increases expected by Wall Street may well be inconsistent with providing first-class health care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Behind a nondescript facade on a quiet street here, huge looms with thousands of needles are noisily working their magic in rhythm, transforming rolls of plain fabric into delicate designs that will one day adorn a fancy nightgown, frilly underwear or a little girl's party dress. Punctuating the dance are the quick movements of a nimble-fingered worker known as a ''watcher,'' who jumps in when a skein of yarn snaps, rethreading the needle and marking the problem spot with tape, even as the machine continues to pulsate.

headline.main: In New Jersey, a Delicate Industry Unravels

docs.abstract: Once-flourishing embroidery industry in Hudson and Bergen Counties, NJ, faces troubled times; more embroidery is produced here than in any other region in nation, but business is rapidly shrinking, raising concerns that it will eventually succumb to same forces that have killed off other manufacturing trades in area; in last 15 years, New Jersey's share of domestic market for embroidery has declined to 70 percent from 90 percent; photo of Ed Parseghian, president of Deerbrook Fabrics (M)
